is a self-proclaimed "living ghost town" in

Dating back to 1862 and once a silver mining boomtown (hence the name, from "silver chloride") with 2000 residents, the mining pretty much dried up by 1944 and most of the town along with it.  Chloride today hosts about 250 people, many retired, and subsists on a trickle of tourism.  If you want a taste of the Old West
any tacky commercialism, this just might be your ticket.
Chloride is off Highway 93, 18 mi north of
.  Turn at mile marker 53 onto Mohave County Route 125 and drive for four miles.
Chloride can comfortably be covered on foot.

There is a mine shaft open to tourists on odd days. The desert landscape is fairly beautiful and quite serene, and provides a perfect backdrop to this little piece of Americana. No other major tourist attractions.

value: content=This aptly named restaurant is a time warp back to the 1920s.  Good if fairly basic grub, a surprisingly good selection of regional beers, live entertainment on many evenings.
content=The only place in town to sleep, with eight adobe rooms.
